awd_titl_txt: A conference to encourage and support women creating and distributing STEM media
awd_abstract_narration:
In both the STEM media and entertainment sectors women are significantly unrepresented. Women account for only 21% of the upper-level positions in film (directors, writers, executive producers, cinematographers, etc.) according to a recent study. This small conference directly addresses how to expand the volume of STEM focused media and entertainment content centered on women and girls. The Creative Workforce Summit: Women Storytellers Explore STEM will be held in New York City and online (hybrid) in September 2022.  The goal of the conference is to 1) encourage an infrastructure of support for the creation and distribution of informal STEM educational film, digital, and television content that is centered on women and girls and 2)  to strengthen ties between women in media, entertainment, and women in STEM fields. The agenda includes keynote addresses by thought leaders in STEM disciplines and media, panels of industry leaders, a youth journalist interviews, and  film screenings with filmmaker and scientist Q&As. The conference will be a  hybrid event to allow for the greatest access to a broader audience. The projected 300 in-person and 1000+ virtual attendees will be drawn from New York Women in Film and Television’s  extensive membership and 100+ partner organizations in entertainment and media, including Black Public Media, Brown Girls Doc Mafia, Firelight Media, ReelAbilities, and the National Association of Latino Independent Producers.  The conference will be followed by a publication based on the convening featuring the keynotes, abridged panel discussions, additional interviews, and industry representation data analysis. In addition,  a  curriculum guide  for high schools and colleges focused on STEM and film collaborations will be developed and distributed.   

A post conference quantitative  survey will be conducted  with conference participants to gather data on the impacts of the conference.  Questions to be asked include:    What new professional connections were made by women attending the conference? What was learned related to the craft of STEM related media production and distribution? Were new and meaningful connections made with participants outside the participant’s current field/networks?   Additional analysis will be done by the organizers of the conference in planning post-conference strategies for supporting and building the women in STEM infrastructure.   

This small conference project  is funded by the Advancing Informal STEM Learning (AISL) program, which seeks to (a) advance new approaches to and evidence-based understanding of the design and development of STEM learning in informal environments; (b) provide multiple pathways for broadening access to and engagement in STEM learning experiences; (c) advance innovative research on and assessment of STEM learning in informal environments; and (d) engage the public of all ages in learning STEM in informal environments.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

New York Women in Film & Television

4th Annual Creative Workforce Summit 2023: 

STEM and Storytelling

 

Final Report

National Science Foundation

Advancing Informal STEM Learning Program

 

"Don't let anyone rob you of your imagination, your creativity, or your curiosity.

It's your place in the world; it's your life. 

Go on and do all you can with it and make it the life you want to live.”

Mae Jemison (Engineer, Physician, Former NASA Astronaut,

and the first Black woman to travel into space)

 

In both the media and entertainment field and STEM women continue to be radically unrepresented. Women account for only 21% of the upper-level positions in film (directors, writers, executive producers, cinematographers, etc.) according to a recent study by The Center for the Study of Women in Television and Film at San Diego State University. This means that almost 80% of entertainment products are created by men, and overwhelmingly white men. In STEM, women make up only 28% of the workforce in science, technology, engineering, and math, according to a recent study by the American Association of University Women (AAUW) and only 9% of mechanical engineers of women. Encouraging collaboration between women content creators and women in STEM creates a powerful lever for overall societal change. As the 4th Annual New York Women in Film & Television Summit: STEM and Storytelling opening keynote speaker Aerospace Engineer Dr. Tiera Fletcher explained “When I saw [the film] Hidden Figures, I saw myself times three. I saw Mary Jackson. I saw Katherine Johnson. I saw Dorothy Vaughn. By looking at those women, I saw possibility.”

NYWIFT’s STEM and Storytelling Summit brought together leading women in STEM with filmmakers and entertainment industry thought-leaders for a transdisciplinary exploration of content by and about women in STEM with a particular focus on public health, space, and climate change. The Summit opened doors to new relationships, conversations, and collaborations with the goal of ultimately creating a richer, more diverse pipeline of STEM-focused entertainment content by and about women and girls, particularly from underrepresented groups. Distributing more diverse and varied stories will increase the percentage of underrepresented groups in both fields. From untold histories to visions of the future, the Summit examined informal STEM education in entertainment by focusing on best practices, successful interventions, and daring, proposed solutions by women in these sectors, which continue to struggle for equity and representation. All sections were designed with an overarching focus on increasing the amount of screen STEM content created about and by women and girls. 

The three-day convening featured keynote addresses, conversations, and panels from STEM and entertainment industry leaders, such as the former NASA astronaut and Director of Johnson Space Center Dr. Ellen Ochoa and Magic School Bus Executive Producer Jane Startz. Panels included :

  • Women’s Healthcare: Societal Challenges & Medical Innovations (featuring Paula Eiselt: Director/Producer, Aftershock; Dr. Marc Schiffman: Executive Co-Director Weill Cornell Fibroid and Adenomyosis Center; Maria Hinojosa: Award-winning Journalist/Executive Producer) 
  • Medical Advancements Onscreen and on the Horizon (featuring Lisa Hepner: Director/Writer/Producer, The Human Trial; Leslie Fields-Cruz, Executive Director, Black Public Media)
  • Climate Change: Using Media to Inform, Educate, and Prepare for the Imminent Crisis (featuring William Kenworthey: Regional Leader Urban Design HOK; Caitlin Saks: NOVA Senior Producer; Yvonne Russo: Award-winning producer/director/writer)
  • Case Study: Short and Long-Form STEM Programming (featuring Ntokozo Mbuli: Series Creator (Vutha); William Caballero: Guggenheim Fellow/Creative Capital recipient; Annetta Marion: Primetime Emmy-nominated director/ showrunner; Melissa Adeyemo: CEO/Founder, Ominira Studios)
  • Crisis Women in the Sci-Fi Director’s Chair (featuring Ayoka Chenzira: Director, HERadventure, Kindred; Eunice Levis; Writer/Director, Invade, Ro & the Stardust; Michèle Stephenson: Award-winning filmmaker/artist/author)
  • Children’s STEM Programming – Inspiring the Next Generation (featuring Maria Agui Carter: Director/Series Producer/Advisor, Latina Sci-Girls; Christina Delfico: iDig2Learn, Founder/Independent Producer; Dorothy Bennett: Director, Creative Pedagogy, New York Hall of Science; Jane Startz: Multi-Emmy producer, president of Jane Startz Productions.; Maribel Lopez: Senior Director/ Head of PBS Digital Studios)

In addition to the opening keynote “It’s Rocket Science: Inspiring the Next Generation of Women Aerospace Engineers” from Tiera Fletcher, Director of Innovations and Biotechnology of the Fibroid Center for Weill Cornell Medicine Dr. Tamatha Fenster addressed the conference with “Innovation and Creativity in the GYN Doctor’s Bag: Redesigning the Women’s Health”.

The convening is followed by an 80-page publication exploring and documenting conversations and lessons learned during the three days, including additional materials on the impact of media role models on girls and young women in STEM and a National Endowment for the Arts funded screening series of STEM focused films at the Brooklyn Academy of Music (BAM).
